Package edu.bu.pas.pokemon.core

Class Pokemon

java.lang.Object
edu.bu.pas.pokemon.core.Pokemon
public class Pokemon extends Object
A class that represents a pokemon in this implementation of gen-1 pokemon battling. A pokemon is really just a bunch of values. Some values describe how powerful the pokemon is, while others describe what moves that pokemon has learned, while others describe how healthy the pokemon is. A gen-1 pokemon at its core is a named creature with at most two types:
  • dexIdx: the index of this pokemon in a PokeDex.
  • names[]: This is a pair of names. The first entry is the name of the species of pokemon (i.e. "Pikachu"). The second entry is the nickname given to this pokemon. If you choose to give a pokemon a nickname, that nickname will be used to refer to that pokemon in the rendering. Otherwise, the species name is used.
  • originalTypes[]: Each pokemon has at most two types. These values are determined beforehand by the species of pokemon (you have no control over this). However, there are some moves in pokemon that allow you to change the type(s) of your pokemon. Therefore, this field is used to store the original types of this pokemon.
  • currentTypes[]: As mentioned in the previous item, there are moves that change a pokemon's type(s). So, this field stores the current type(s) of this pokemon. This is reset back to the original types when a pokemon is swapped out.
Pokemon also have stats. The first stat a pokemon has is its level, which is an integer from 1 to 100 inclusive. In the normal pokemon games, you level up your pokemon as you battle with them, but in this implementation this is just a number that you choose. The larger the level, the more powerful the pokemon (in general). Pokemon also have other stats that control how hard their damage-dealing moves hit, how tough they are when being hit with damage-dealing moves, how fast they are, etc. One of the most important of these stats is their HP, or "health points". A Pokemon's HP starts out at some positive value, and decreases when that pokemon is dealt damage. When a pokemon's HP becomes zero, that pokemon faints and is unusable for the remainder of the battle. See Stat for the other types of stats. A pokemon stores stats in a few ways:
  • ivs[]: This array stores one integer per Stat. IVs, or "Individual Values", are stats that describe how powerful specific instances of a pokemon species are. In the pokemon games, you may encounter (and capture) multiple individuals of the same pokemon species. Each individual is given their own IVs, which help make individuals different. In the pokemon games, IVs are psuedo-randomly generated, but here you get to choose these values for your teams. IVs are in the range of [1, 15] except for the ACC and EVASIVE stats, which should get values of 1. Click here for more information.

  • evs[]: This array stores one integer per Stat. EVs or "Effort Values" describe how powerful you pokemon becomes after defeating opponents. Based on the pokemon you defeat, your pokemon will grow in different ways, which is described by the EVs. In the pokemon games, you can control how your pokemon grow by controlling who they defeat, but here you get to choose these values for your teams. In gen1, EVs are stored using two-byte numbers, meaning that you can have a maximum EV for a particular stat of 65535 (except ACC/EVASIVE which have a max value of 1). Click here for more information.

  • baseStats[]: Each pokemon species has an initial stat combination that helps differentiate one species from another. You have no control over this.
  • initialStats[]: Once the baseStats, IVs, EVs, and level are known, the initial stats of a pokemon are calculated from a mathematical formula. We are using gen-1 pokemon, and I have implemented the gen-1 initial stats formulae. Click here for more information.

  • currentStats[]: This array holds the current stats of a pokemon. A Pokemon's stats can change during battle. Most of the time, a Pokemon's HP stat will change, but there are moves that can buff and/or debuff Pokemon, so the other stats may change as well. This array holds the current values of each stat.

  • statMultipliers[]: The way a Pokemon's stats may change during a battle (besides HP which changes when being dealt damage or recovering health) are goverened by stat mutlipliers. These values, sometimes called "stage multipliers", are coefficients that scale the initial stats to calculate the current stats (remember except HP). We are using the stage multiplier rules found here. We are using the gen II rules for ACC/EVASIVE and the gen I-II rules for all other stats.
During battle, Pokemon can be afflicted with a variety of persistent statuses like falling asleep, being frozen, etc. A Pokemon can only be affected by a single status effect at a time, so if a pokemon is currently asleep it *cannot* be burned, etc. The only exception to this rule is the move rest which puts your pokemon to sleep in exchange for resetting its HP back to full. When resting, the sleep status will replace whatever current persistent status that Pokemon has. Persistent statuses are called non volatile statuses and the full list can be seen by examining the NonVolatileStatus enum.

There are other volatile statuses that a Pokemon can be afflicted with. These are called volatile statuses because they reset when a pokemon is switch out (unlike NonVolatileStatuses). These volatile statuses contain things like confusion, being trapped (where your pokemon cannot be switched out until it wears off), flinching, etc. For a full list of volatile statuses, please examine the Flag enum.

Some volatile statuses and non volatile statuses wear off over time. Each status has counters, which are stored in fields such as:
  • nonVolatileStatusCounters[]: One counter per NonVolatileStatus value.
  • flagCounters[]: One counter per Flag value.
If you want to check the duration of a status, you can always go to its counter to examine the turns remaining.

Pokemon can do moves that change their heights on the battlefield. For instance, the multi-turn move fly takes two turns. On the first turn, the pokemon soars up into the air (i.e. is now higher than ground level). On turn two, the pokemon dives out of the sky and delivers a big bonk to the target before landing back at ground level. There are other moves that change the height besides fly. Either way, some moves can only hit pokemon when that pokemon is at ground level, and will automatically miss if that pokemon is not at ground level. So, a pokemon contains its current height on the battlefield. Please see the Height enum for the complete list of gen-1 options.

A Pokemon also retains a reference back to the Team that that pokemon belongs to. So, given a pokemon, you can always trace back to its team without doing an expensive search operations.
A Pokemon is capable of using at most four learnable moves. These four moves are stored in an array, and if the pokemon does not know four moves, then some of these entries will be null. Note that a pokemon must be equipped with at least one move, but cannot learn more than four.

Finally, a pokemon contains some fields that are necessary for some nieche moves to work:
  • lastMoveHitBy: This is the last move that affected this pokemon. Some moves allow you to copy moves that just struck you.
  • activeMove: This field is not null when your pokemon is locked into doing a multi-turn move.
  • lastDamageDealt: This contains the amount of damage this pokemon was last hit with. Some moves do damage as a function of how hard the casting pokemon was hit.
  • statsUnchangeable: This boolean is true only after some nieche moves that prevent a pokemon's stats from being modified for a few turns.
  • substitute: This field contains a Pokemon.Substitute instance if the move Substitute has been used and the resulting substitute has not been broken yet.
